title: Towards Hybrid NER: A Study of Content and Crowdsourcing-Related Performance Factors

The talk is on.
An approach towards hybrid named entity recognition and it's a study of content and crowdsourcing related factors.
And just a bit to give you the motivation of this problem.

Now, considering you have these two tweets and the first one looks like something that's taken from the news article, while the second one looks like what you'd traditionally see on Twitter, how do you perform named entity recognition on this suites and this?
We all know that named entity recognition is an important first step when you're doing information extraction.
When you want to build semantic systems.
So given these two tweets, what do you do?
The current state of the art.
Has started advocating on using hybrid platforms.

Now the way hybrid platforms work is you first pass the tweets through your traditional machine based tools, so this could be either APIs like Alchemy API, also mental open Kelly or you can use standalone tools like the Stanford Tools.
Now, what traditionally happens is you have all these tweets that fall off just because of the nature of how tweets are.
So tweets tend to be very short.
They have ambiguous statements, inconsistent capitalizations, urban spellings, collapse words.
All these things make it difficult for you to use your traditional systems to carry out proper named entity recognition.
So what then happens is you pass some of these tweets to the crowd.
And they start doing a good job and in some cases they don't do a very good job 'cause they're just in cases which are quite ambiguous even for experts.
So you have to figure out what tweets do I pass to the crowd?
What tweets do I pass my machine tools and probably what sweets do?
I also passed to the experts.

'cause currently we have very high precision and recall values when you use news articles.

What do they perform well at?
What kind of entities are they good at spotting and this would help us make an informed decision on how we can build the entire pipeline.
Once we select this, we can decide these other ones go to the to the machines and this ones which are very very difficult.
Probably go to experts.
Now our hypothesis were on 2 broad categories.
The first thing we thought was there are probably some factors in the tweets inherent in the tweets themselves that make them more suited to the crowd.

Maybe they like long tweets 'cause it's more conversational and has more discussed just like the news articles.

What kind of entities are they more interested in?
